Description: Two fragments, not joined, from a corroded iron object or possibly two different items. The smaller is made of a curved sheet of metal in the shape of a kind of carving gouge, larger on the side of the edge and narrower on the other end (the tang ?), which is broken. The larger one is made of a flat piece of metal, rounded at its narrower end and broken at the other, larger end surrounded by an oval ferrule made of a large stripe of metal. The two parts are stuck together by corrosion mixed with what might be organic material (wood?). This item might be interpreted as the central part of a tool or knife with a handle fixed by a ferrule.
Curator's comments: Items interpreted as a "part of bit, or knife in metal sheath" in the Museum register which refers to W.M.F. Petrie, Tanis ii, Nebesheh and Defenneh, p. 79 § 78. This would mean that they might have been part of the "large quantity of iron scraps, apparently of workman's scrap heap (...) found in the camp".
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1888 / Tanis. Part II. Nebesheh (Am) and Defenneh (Tahpanhes) (p. 79 § 78) (?)
Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.75, p.184, pl.26)
